title-group.article-title: Letter to the Editor, “Tooth Bleaching Increases Dentinal Protease Activity”

body.p: We have concerns related to the interpretation of the findings and experimental design of the article by Sato et al. (2013):

(1) The statement “Despite reports that the use of bleaching agents at low concentrations has been considered absolutely safe…” lacks supporting citations. Bleaching agents at any concentration could be potentially harmful to tooth structures (Azer et al., 2009; Goldberg et al., 2010), and no bleaching is “absolutely safe”. This study lacked control groups with low H2O2. Lower H2O2 could have caused the same changes as those described by the authors.

(2) Despite their awareness that it is the acidity of a bleaching gel that harms hard tissues and activates the MMPs that degrade collagen, the authors did not provide the pH of the bleaching gel. Carrier agents (e.g., polyacrylic acid) may also contribute to the acidity of bleaching gels. This study lacked carrier controls. Carrier agents alone could have caused the same tissue changes (Toteda et al., 2008; Soldani et al., 2010).

(3) Enamel permeability is higher in youngsters, but decreases significantly with age (Kotsanos and Darling, 1991; Bertacci et al., 2007). Therefore, this study may apply only to younger teeth with high permeability, but not to older patients seeking bleaching treatments.

(4) The statement that “3 consecutive 15-minute applications of 35% H2O2 induced ROS generation” does not appear correct, since the ROS experimentation was actually done after 3 times the 3 consecutive 15-minute applications, which is aggressive for young teeth used in this study.

(5) The claim that bleaching “provokes biological responses of dental tissues that can be clinically long term” appears to be beyond the scope of the study, since no teeth were examined beyond one day after treatment.

fn.p: The author of this letter has no consulting arrangement and received no support in any form for any products used in this study.
